 Second: Try this: Start - Programs - Accessories - System Tools - System Restore. Then pick a date when your computer was working properly and restore to that date's settings.  hmmm. try this. Right click anywhere on the screen so you get to display properties. Then go to screen saver - power. Then click on the "advance" tab and change the power button setting to "when I press the power buttom on my computer" change that to shutdown. 
 
 but there's likely a very simple problem. you likely have some independent program running in the background that is interfering with shutdown. http://www.processlibrary.com, go to that site and type in your running processes from the Task Manager. Sure it's tedious but its likely to reveal the problem.

The other day we had a storm and somehow, someway, my wife's computer got its operating system messed up even though it was turned off. I guess something came in through the ethernet connection. I can't turn it off. I am reduced to pulling the plug. I tried to reinstall the operating system but it won't let me because it says I have a later version installed. I am not going to do a reformat or anything like that. Other than that it seems to work normally, although it seems to take a little longer to boot up. What's the best, quick and dirty way to fix this problem? It has XP Pro. It's a Dell 2400.

 
 1. Boot from the windowsXP install CD (make sure you boot from it).
 2. When it asks you to install a new version or repair an existing one, chose the install.
 3. When it asks where to put the install, choose the disk with the OS on it. 
 4. It will give you a warning, but ignore it.
 5. It will ask you whether to format or delete a partition. Try formating the partition (you'll lose all info on disk), if that doesn't work delete the partition all together and then format.
 6. Re-install OS.
 
 If you still can't make the OS stick, make a new partition and load the OS onto that, then reformat your HD.
 
 If you think it is the BIOS, try re-flashing your BIOS. Look at the manufacturer's website for detail on that.
 
 Hope that helps.
Missouri Mule

 5. It will ask you whether to format or delete a partition. Try formating the partition (you'll lose all info on disk), if that doesn't work delete the partition all together and then format.
 6. Re-install OS.
 
 If you still can't make the OS stick, make a new partition and load the OS onto that, then reformat your HD.
 
 If you think it is the BIOS, try re-flashing your BIOS. Look at the manufacturer's website for detail on that.
 
 Hope that helps.

OK, this is where I am dumb, dumb, dumb. I inserted the CD into the computer at startup but it didn't boot from it. What should I have done? Do I like hit F12 or something like that?

 
 When your computer boot, right after the beep, press F2 or Del. 
 
 This will send you into the BIOS for your motherboard.
 
 Hunt around for the option "boot order" or some such thing. 
 
 Choose the order: 1. Floppy, 2. CD-Rom, 3. HD
 
 Save the settings and exit the BIOS.
 
 Insert the CD and boot from it.
Missouri Mule

 Go to "Run" on your start menu and type msconfig
 
 Goto the last tab that says start up.
 
 If you have a lot of stuff checked, uncheck the stuff you know you won't need. Reboot.
 
 Next defrag your drive.
 
 If that still doesn't work, you might have other issues...

daewoo

If it is an electrical problem, it may well be amain board problem. You cannot turn modern computers "off" unless they are either unplugged or the switch ont he power supply is in the "off" positon (ont heback of the ocmputer). The rest fo the time the computer is always pulling some current. A lightning strik to the line or somethign similar can still fry the machine.
 
 Do you have it plugged into a good surge protector? the things you buy at walk mart for $6 are not good surge protectors. A good surge protector will cost you about $100. Also (I know it sounds stupid), is the computefr crounded? have you ever used a plug tester to ensure that the outlet the computer is plussged into has a solid ground? fro most things it does not matter. With computers, it does.
 
 If it is not a hardware problem, your best bet is probably to make backups of your files then do a fromat and re-install. That is just the price of running windows. A better solution than burning CDs or DVDs may be (depending on the amout of data to back up) to get an extra hard drive. You can pick up a 20-30 gb drive on Ebay for song and a dance. Install it in your amchine, format it witha fat32 file system (NOT NTFS, which can only be read by NT based machines or linux).
 
 Backup your files to your new, small hard drive. Load windows ME, THEN load windows XP. You will end up with a dual boot machine. A menu will pop up for a second each time you boot with the option of booting to either XP or windows ME. That way when XP crashes you still have a graphical OS to work from in repairing it.

 Mule, follow these directions.
 
 Start - Adminstrative Tools - Computer Management - Under Storage click on "disk management." That should tell you the health of your drive. 
 
 If adminstrative tools are not there, go to taskbar and start menu properties, start menu, customize and then check the box that says "display adminstrative tools."

In the old days of DOS I just did a chkdsk /f and it would be taken care of. Can I still do that by going into DOS while having XP Pro as my operating system?

 
 Chkdsk is a disk tool in XP. Once you run it you will have to reboot for it run. It requires control of the OS to run a thorough disk check.
 
 Have you checked your BIOS setting on you power settings?

Assume for the purposes of this question that I am a blooming idiot. Walk me through the steps here exactly what I am to do. I want to run something that will tell me for sure whether or not there is a physical problem with the disk. That's the first step I need to do before I attempt any repair. I was doing a defragmenting and I was told by "System Mechanic 5" that I needed to do a scandisk but I can't even find it listed as an executable file in XP. And if there is a physical problem in the "boot sector" can it even be repaired?

 
 
 Ok, next time I'm charging you! HA! Just kidding.
 
 Ok, double click 'my comp' on your OS HD right click and choose the 'tools' tab. There should be a scan disk. Chose it, and check all tests. Click 'ok' and it will ask you if you want to reboot.
 
 If it is not your disk after that, you can try 4 things.
 1. Reset you BIOS to defaults.
 2. Reflash your BIOS
 3. Check your drivers
 4. typing fdisk /mbr to fix the master boot record. Unfortunately you will need a Windows 95/98/Me boot floppy for that. If you ask nice I might be able to e-mail you a boot file! Heh...ya got to beg though!
daewoo
Or go to www.bootdisk.com and save groveling for a later time
Missouri Mule

It's fixed. Reformatted and reinstalled. Learned a good deal and I'll know what to do the next time. I can't explain it but it appears that there was about 16 copies of the operating system installed. That was what was slowing down the start-up. Now it is humming like a fine tuned engine. Still have to install the latest video driver but it is fine now. Thanks to everyone for their advice.
